Fig. 1 Synthetic routes of HCFO-1233zd(Z). Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) and (b) Selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) on the different catalysts activated at different temperatures. (c) Conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) and (d) Selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) on commercial α-AlF3 calcined at different temperature. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of γ-Al2O3 activated by CHF3 at different activation temperatures (a) before and (b) after the reaction. Fig 3 Fig. 4 SEM images of γ-Al2O3 activated by CHF3 at different activation temperatures: (a) γ-Al2O3, (b) 350 °C, (c) 400 °C, (d) 450 °C, (e) 500 °C, (f) 550 °C. Fig 4 Fig. 5 27Al MAS NMR spectra of (a) commercial γ-Al2O3 and the catalyst activated at 350 °C, (b) the catalysts activated at 400 and 450 °C, (c) the catalysts activated at 500 and 550 °C, (d) the catalyst activated at 550 °C and the commercial AlF3. Measured at 15 kHz, D1=5 s, ns=660. *: spinning side bands. Fig 5 Fig. 6 19F MAS NMR spectra of the catalyst activated at (a) 350 °C, (b) 400 °C, (c) 450 °C. Measured at 18 kHz, D1=10 s, ns=320. *: spinning side bands. Fig 6 Fig. 7 NH3 desorption profiles of catalysts activated at (a) 350 °C, (b) 400 °C, (c) 450 °C, (d) 500 °C, (e) 550 °C. Fig 7 Fig. 8 FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine after evacuation at (i) 150 °C and (ii) 350 °C: (a) commercial γ-Al2O3, and the catalysts activated at (b) 350 °C, (c) 400 °C, (d) 450 °C, (e) 500 °C, (f) 550 °C. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) (Black dots) and Selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) (Red squares). The evaluation was carried out at 270 °C, GHSV of 120 h−1. Fig 9 Fig. 10 SEM images of (a) γ-Al2O3 activated by CHF3 at 450 °C for 48 h, (b) after 100 h evaluation and (c) γ-Al2O3 activated by HCFO-1233zd(E) at 270 °C for 24 h. Investigation on fluorinated alumina catalysts prepared by the fluorination of γ-Al2O3 with CHF3 for the isomerization of E-1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene Shiwei Feng Methodology Writing – original draft Chengping Zhang Methodology Writing – review & editing ⁎ Hengdao Quan Writing – original draft ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, 5 South Zhongguancun Street, Beijing 100081, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology 5 South Zhongguancun Street Beijing 100081 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, 5 South Zhongguancun Street, Beijing 100081, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. As an environmentally friendly cleaning agent, Z-1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233zd(Z)) can realize industrial production by the isomerization of HCFO-1233zd(E). Herein, various isomerization catalysts with different structures, compositions and acid properties were prepared through the fluorination of γ-Al2O3 with CHF3 by controlling the activation conditions. For the first time, the catalysts for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization were systematically studied by XRD, N2 physisorption, XPS, SEM, MAS NMR spectroscopy, NH3-TPD and py-IR. The active site of this reaction was revealed and the catalyst deactivation mechanism was proposed. It turned out that HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization prefers to occur at Lewis acid sites with moderate density and strength. The amorphous particles composed of γ-Al2O3, Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 ( R 3 ¯ c ) at 450 °C exhibit highly catalytic activity for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization. After 100 h evaluation, it was found that residual γ-Al2O3 can be fluorinated by HCFO-1233zd(E) to form needle-like structures which could induce the amorphous Al2O3(F) particles to reorganize and give cubic structures, where the Lewis acid properties were enhanced, leading to catalyst deactivation. Graphical abstract Synopsis: The amorphous particles composed of γ-Al2O3, Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 ( R 3 ¯ c ) exhibit highly catalytic activity for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization. After 100 h evaluation, the amorphous particles were induced by HCFO-1233zd(E) to reorganize and give cubic structures with enhanced Lewis acid properties, therefore leading to catalyst deactivation. HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization on γ-Al2O3 fluorinated by CHF3. Image, graphical abstract Keywords E-1-chloro-3,3,3-fluoropropene Z-1-chloro-3,3,3-fluoropropene Fluorinated alumina Lewis acid sites Acid strength Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nowadays, hydrochlorofluoolefins (HCFOs) have been developed to replace chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). First, the presence of the C=C double bond could promote the reaction between organic molecules and OH radicals [1,2], and the oxidation products can be removed from the atmosphere by wet and dry deposition on a time scale of days to weeks [3], thus the atmospheric lifetime is significantly shortened [4,5]. Second, considerably smaller radiative efficiencies (REs) of HCFOs mean significantly lower global warming potentials (GWP) [6]. Last but not least, most of HCFOs are degraded to acid chloride and acid fluoride which are not ozone-depleting because Cl (sp2) atom is attached to the C=C double bond, only a very small fraction can be degraded to chlorine radicals and reach the stratosphere where they participate in catalyzed ozone depletion, indicating their negligible influence on ozone depletion [7]. Besides, the introduction of chlorine atom enhances the solubility and improves the cleaning performance, such as 1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233zd) [8], 1-chloro-2,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233yd) [9] and 1-chloro-2,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropene (HCFO-1224yd) [10], etc. Herein, Z-1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233zd(Z)) is one of the typical representatives among HCFOs with a short atmospheric lifetime of only 14 d, global warming potential at 100 year horizon (GWP100) value less than 1, nearly non-ozone depletion [11] and relatively high Kauri-butanol (KB) value of 34. With excellent performance in degreasing cutting oil, spindle oil and hydraulic oil, HCFO-1233zd(Z) can be used as the cleaning agent to replace the widely used 1,1-dichloro-1-fluoroethane (HCFC-141b) with a KB value of 56. Moreover, its relatively high boiling point of 39 °C facilitates cleaning operations at room temperature [8]. As shown in Fig. 1 , HCFO-1233zd(Z) can be obtained as the main product by selective hydrogenation from 1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropyne [12], selective hydrogen chloride addition from 3,3,3-trifluoropropyne (TFPY) [13] and isomerization from E-1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233zd(E)). Among these synthetic routes, HCFO-1233zd(Z) is industrialized mainly by isomerization of HCFO-1233zd(E), the other two routes are not suitable for industrial production because the raw materials are not easily available and the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) is too low. In addition, HCFO-1233zd(E), with an atmospheric lifetime of 26 d, GWP100 value of 7 and nearly non-ozone depletion, can be easily obtained by gas phase fluorine-chlorine exchange reaction using 1,1,1,3,3-pentachloropropane (HCC-240fa) as raw material, and widely used to replace the refrigerant 1,1,1-trifluoro-2,2-dichloroethane (HCFC-123) and 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane (HFC-134a), as well as the substitute of blowing agent 1,1,1,3,3-pentafluoropropane (HFC-245fa). According to relevant literatures, the isomerization from HCFO-1233zd(E) to HCFO-1233zd(Z) can be catalyzed by various chemical compounds under different conditions. For example, when catalyzed by alloys, such as stainless steel, Inconel 625 or Monel 400, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) was rather low at 300 °C, unless the temperature increased to 400∼500 °C and the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) was greater than 90%, leading to higher production costs [14,15]; when catalyzed by AlF3, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) was similarly low as temperature ranging from 200 °C to 300 °C [16]; when catalyzed by chromium oxyfluoride, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) increased with the elevation of reaction temperature, but the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) decreased on the contrary [17]; when catalyzed by free radical initiators, the reaction required a high temperature of 450 °C to increase the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z), which makes industrialization uneconomical in the same way [18]; when catalyzed by chromium supported on activated carbon or γ-Al2O3 fluorinated by HF, the isomerization reaction was fed with HCFO-1233zd(E) containing 14% HF in mole fraction, where the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) exceeded 15%, but selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) was less than 70% [19]; when catalyzed by zirconium supported on γ-Al2O3, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) decreased in the progress of the reaction, which means the catalyst activity was unstable [19]; when catalyzed by AlCl0.1F2.9 or SbF5 supported on tungsten oxyfluoride, although the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) was significantly improved, the catalyst was deactivated over time possibly due to the carbon deposition or the loss of active component [20,21]. Apparently, the key factor in producing HCFO-1233zd(Z) from HCFO-1233zd(E) is closely attached to the catalyst which should have the characteristics of excellent catalytic activity, long performance life span and strong stability. As mentioned above, several metal oxides, hydroxyfluorides, and fluorides have been reported to be used as isomerization catalysts in various patents. However, the scientific connections including crystal structure, the strength and the type of acid sites between the catalyst and the catalytic activity are still unknown, which seriously affects the development of catalysts with excellent activity for the isomerization of HCFO-1233zd(E). In this work, γ-Al2O3 was chosen as the precursor because it was reported to be constructive in the isomerization of alkene [22,23], as well as the excellent mechanical stability and adjustable acid-base properties. From the point view of convenience and safety, CHF3 was preferred as the fluorination agent due to its nontoxic and noncorrosive nature. After activation in CHF3 flow to give sufficient catalytic activity, the catalyst was used to explore the correlation between its intrinsic properties and catalytic performance of the HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization. The structure, morphology and composition of the catalysts were studied by XRD, N2 physisorption, XPS, SEM and MAS NMR. Their acidic characteristics were characterized by py-IR and NH3-TPD. By comparing the similarities and differences of the characterization results, the main reasons affecting the catalytic activity of HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization were summarized. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The γ-Al2O3 pellet (Φ4–6 mm), with a surface area of 188 m2/g and total pore volume of 0.52 cm3/g, was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd; the α-AlF3 powder (99%), with a surface area of 3 m2/g and total pore volume of 0.01 cm3/g, was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd; the activation reagent CHF3 (99.99%) was purchased from Shangfluoro Technology Co., Ltd. In all cases, catalyst precursors were crushed or compressed, then sieved to 10–20 mesh. Approximately 10 mL sieved precursors were set into a vertical Monel 400 reactor of length 360 mm and inner diameter 9.88 mm, which was held in the middle of the reactor supported by 10 mL α-Al2O3. The reactor was heated in a cylindrical furnace which was equipped with a temperature controller and a thermocouple reaches the central portion of the reactor. The lining from the raw material tank to the reactor and the reactor outlet line were also heated with heating bands to prevent any condensation. After calcination in N2 flow at 350 °C for 12 h, dried catalyst precursors were activated by the flow of CHF3 and N2 adjusted by mass flow controllers (Beijing Sevenstar Electronics) to 25 and 100 mL/min respectively at 350, 400, 450, 500, 550 °C for 24 h. 2.2 Catalytic activity tests After activation, lower the temperature to 290 °C and stop the CHF3 and N2 flow, then charge the raw material HCFO-1233zd(E) with the gas flow rate of 10 mL/min controlled by a mass flow controller (Beijing Sevenstar Electronics), and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of the system was 60 h−1. The gas effluent from the reactor was washed with water to remove HCl and/or HF formed, then analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Agilent GC8890) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a DB-VRX capillary column (60 m × 0.32 mm), using the following operating conditions: carrier gas, 25 mL/min; injector temperature, 200 °C; temperature, 40 °C (5 min) to 120 °C (20 min, at 20 °C/min). The conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) and selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) were defined as follows: Conversion of HCFO − 1233 zd ( E ) = n ( detectable products ) n ( HCFO... 1233 zd ( E ) in feed ) × 100 % Selectivity of HCFO − 1233 zd ( Z ) = n ( HCFO... 1233 zd ( Z ) in product ) n ( detectable products ) × 100 % 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The crystalline structures of the catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, HAOYUAN DX-27mini) with Cu-Kα radiation ( l = 1.540 Å ). Phases were identified by comparison with the ICSD powder diffraction file. To semi-quantitatively analyze the surface elemental composition of the catalysts, X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) was used by PHI5000, with an X-ray source of Mono Al-Kα, 1486.6 eV. The shift of binding energy was corrected by the C 1 s level at 284.8 eV. Curve fitting was performed using the software PHI Multipak. Nitrogen sorption experiments were performed on Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ after degasification at 300 °C for 5 h under vacuum. Surface area and porosity were assessed with the BET and BJH model respectively. Morphological and structural information of the catalysts were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, TESCAN MIRA LMS). The samples were prepared by depositing a few droplets of a suspension of the powder in alcohol on silicon wafer. Solid-state MAS (magic angle spinning) nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE NEO 400WB spectrometer with a 3.2 mm DVT probe at room temperature. 27Al MAS NMR one-pulse spectra were recorded at 104.2 MHz, a rotation frequency of 15 kHz, a recycle delay of 5 s and an accumulation number of 640. 19F MAS NMR one-pulse spectra were recorded at 376.5 MHz, a rotation frequency of 18 kHz, a recycle delay of 10 s and an accumulation number of 320. 27Al chemical shifts are referenced to δ = 0 ppm of 1 M Al(NO3)3 solution, 19F chemical shifts are referenced to δ = −74.5 ppm of C2H4O2F3N. Ammonia was used as a probe molecule to assess the strength and number of acid sites in the catalysts. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was carried out on ChemBET Pulsar TPD/TPR, 0.1 g of catalyst was added in a quartz flow reactor, and pre-heated under He flow at 300 °C for 1 h to desorb physisorbed species. After cooling down to 50 °C, ammonia (10% NH3/He) was adsorbed on the surface for 1 h, and the excess was removed by He flow for 1 h. For the desorption, the TPD program was started with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 650 °C, and the desorbed ammonia from the sample was detected by a thermal conductivity detector. The relationship between the integral area and the amount of ammonia was established by using a quantitative loop, in this case, a volume of 28.251 μL NH3 corresponds to a TCD area of 248.55. Thus, the molar quantity of desorbed NH3 can be calculated by the following equation: n ( N H 3 ) = S 1 × 28.251 248.55 × 10 6 × 22.4 Where S 1 is the TCD peak area of desorbed NH3. To identify Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites in the catalysts, infrared spectroscopy of pyridine as the probe molecule (py-IR) was carried out on Tensor 27. 20 mg of catalyst was added to a sample holder made of quartz. All the samples were initially degasified at 350 °C for 2 h. The background spectrum was recorded after the sample was cooled to room temperature, followed by adsorption of pyridine at room temperature for 2 h, and finally sequential evacuation at 150 °C and 350 °C. The calculation of Lewis acid quantity follows the modified Beer-Lambert-Bouguer law [24,25], which is commonly used in FTIR research on solid acid catalysts and is shown as follows: n T = A × S 2 ε × m Where n T is the total number of pyridine per gram of sample; A is the peak area (in cm−1), S 2 is the cross-section of the sample disk ( S 2 = 1.3 cm2), ε is the molar absorption coefficient (cm•μmol−1) and m is the weight of sample disk. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity tests In this experiment, the activation temperatures were controlled to 350, 400, 450, 500 and 550 °C. The reaction temperature and the space velocity for these catalytic activity tests were fixed at 290 °C and 60 h−1 respectively. As shown in Fig. 2 (a) and (b), it was obvious that the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) gradually decreased while the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) significantly increased during isomerization when the catalyst activated at 350 °C. As the activation temperature increased from 350 °C to 500 °C, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) decreased on the whole, while the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) increased on the contrary and reached its highest value at 500 °C. However, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) dramatically dropped to around 2% with the activation temperature further increased to 550 °C. Taking both HCFO-1233zd(E) conversion and HCFO-1233zd(Z) selectivity into account, 450 °C was preferred as the best activation temperature. The sudden decline of HCFO-1233zd(E) could not be simply attributed to the temperature variation because the composition of the catalyst is also variable. Therefore, univariate comparison experiments with only temperature changed were supplemented, where commercial α-AlF3 (99%) was used as the catalyst after calcined at 450, 485, 500, and 550 °C respectively, and then reacted with HCFO-1233zd(E) at 290 °C. The results shown in Fig. 2(c) confirmed that the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) has a similar downtrend compared with Fig. 2(a). When the temperature exceeded a certain level, the catalytic activity decreased. Thus, it can be concluded that temperature could be the main factor leading to catalyst deactivation because temperatures can affect the physical properties of catalysts such as structure distortion in bond angle or length [26–28], ferroelastic behavior [29], thermal expansion [30], etc. Moreover, the highest selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) over commercial α-AlF3 was less than 90% in Fig. 2(d), whereas that over activated γ-Al2O3 could reach 97%, highlighting the excellence of our developed catalyst. 3.1.1 XRD analysis The crystal structures of the catalysts prepared at various temperatures were analyzed by XRD, and Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of different catalysts before and after the reaction. No obvious structural changes to γ-Al2O3 were seen at 350 °C, but the diffraction experiment does not rule out the possibility of low-level fluorination of the surface. When the activation temperature was elevated to 400 °C, it was obvious that the diffraction peak of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 10–0425) at 2θ = 37°, 45°, 67° decreased, while the fluorinated phase that grown on γ-Al2O3 resembled α-AlF3 (JCPDS 80–1007) at 2θ = 25°, 42°, 52°, 58° As the activation temperature further increased, the diffraction peaks of α-AlF3 became narrower and stronger, indicating the growth of crystallite size. By the Debye-Scherrer equation, the average crystallite sizes of α-AlF3 at different activation temperatures were calculated using the width of the 2θ = 25°, which were listed and fitted in supporting information Fig. S1. It described that there is a certain linear relationship between crystallite size of α-AlF3 and activation temperature. Moreover, the (122) crystal plane at 2θ = 59° started to expose when the activation temperature reached 500 °C. Comparing the results before and after the reaction, the diffraction peak of α-AlF3 at 2θ = 25°, 52° appeared while the peak of γ-Al2O3 at 2θ = 37°, 45°, 67° decreased when activated at 350 °C. In addition, the peak intensity of α-AlF3 distinctly increased after the reaction. All these results revealed that γ-Al2O3 and partially fluorinated alumina [Al2O3(F)] can be further fluorinated by HCFO-1233zd(E) during isomerization. When it comes to α-AlF3, it has been well established that α-AlF3 adopts a rhombohedral structure ( R 3 ¯ c ) at room temperature but undergoes a first-order phase transition to the cubic α-ReO3 structure (Pm-3m) at 466 °C [31,32] (see supporting information Fig. S2(a)). This phase transition was associated with the loss of ferroelastic behavior where the observation of ferroelastic domains at room temperature but disappears after phase transition, and it was confirmed that the spontaneous strain is temperature dependent [29]. As presented in Fig. S2(b), it was first proposed by Chupas et al. [26] in 2001 that the Al—F—Al bond angle (ω) is 157.9° when α-AlF3 adopts a rhombohedral structure where the AlF6 octahedra are tilted along their 3-fold axis, but becomes 180° when α-AlF3 adopts a cubic structure where all the AlF6 octahedra are connected by bridging fluorine atoms. In their following group work, the phase transition was studied using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations performed with a polarizable ion model (PIM), in which the Al—F—Al bond angle describes the tilting of the AlF6 corner sharing octahedra as a function of temperature. As the temperature increased, the modified bond angle distribution tended to center at 180° with a residual rhombohedral distortion persisting above the phase transition temperature [27], leading to the decrease of bent Al—F—Al bonds so that the structure is less distorted. Soon after, they applied the combination of Rietveld and pair distribution function (PDF) analyses to investigate changes in Al—F bond lengths through temperature variation and discovered that the Al—F bond length increases steadily with temperature, revealing that the cubic phase contains local octahedral tilts as well [28]. In 2014, Morelock et al. found that the volume thermal expansion of α-AlF3 is strongly positive when the structure is rhombohedral. However, when it transforms to the cubic structure, the volume coefficient of thermal expansion(CTE) drops by fourfold but remains positive to at least 1177 K due to the presence of local octahedral tilts and an associated increase in the average Al—F—Al bond angle on heating [30]. Based on the above studies, the fluorinated phase grows on γ-Al2O3 at different activation temperatures and resembles α-AlF3 but contains significant static disorder which appears to affect the flexibility of the catalyst phase, resulting in drastically different catalytic activity. Once the temperature exceeds the phase transition temperature, the structure of α-AlF3 adopts the cubic structure, leading to deactivation. 3.1.2 XPS and N2 physisorption analysis The surface elemental composition, surface area and porosity of the catalysts were characterized by XPS and N2 physisorption. As shown in Table 1 , when the activation temperature increased from 350 °C to 500 °C, the atomic percentage of Al and O gradually decreased while that of F increased, which is consistent with the XRD results that peak intensities of γ-Al2O3 decreased but α-AlF3 increased. Together with the evaluation results in Fig. 2, it can be concluded that an increase in fluorine content led to an increase in selectivity, while a decrease in oxygen content led to a decrease in conversion because surface hydroxyl groups of γ-Al2O3 could act as Brønsted acid sites, which could be sufficiently strong to protonate the absorbed HCFO-1233zd(E), and then decomposed to by-products, such as vinyl chloride, vinyl fluoride, etc. [33]. As γ-Al2O3 gradually fluorinated, surface hydroxyl groups were replaced by fluorine leading to the decrease of Brønsted acid sites, which in turn could provide more isomerization centers resulting in higher selectivity [33,34]. When the activation temperature reached 550 °C, the atomic percentage of C significantly increased probably due to the formation of carbon deposits. As listed in Table 2 , the surface area and total pore volume decreased with the increase in activation temperature, which is consistent with the literature on the whole [33]. Moreover, the surface area and total pore volume decreased after the isomerization process due to the further fluorination triggered by HCFO-1233zd(E). 3.1.3 SEM analysis The morphology changes of γ-Al2O3 activated by CHF3 at different temperatures were recorded by SEM and shown in Fig. 4 . Apparently, the main differences in these catalysts can be found in the particle shape and size. Commercial γ-Al2O3 is formed by the agglomeration of amorphous or irregular rod-shaped particles. When γ-Al2O3 activated at 350 °C, there was no obvious change probably because of the low-level fluorination. As the activation temperature increased to 400 °C, the fluorinated phase became small amorphous particles, and these particles mildly grew from 400 °C to 450 °C. However, these amorphous particles further grew and became somewhat cubic-like crystals when the activation temperature reached 500 °C where the (122) crystal plane started to expose, and finally became remarkably larger and more three-dimensional at 550 °C. Thus, the variation of crystallite sizes shares the same trend with the XRD results described above. Combined with catalytic activity and XRD results, we speculated that there is a certain relationship between catalytic activity and catalyst morphology. On the one hand, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) exceeded 10% when activated within 450 °C, where the catalysts are probably mainly irregular and amorphous particles representing a mixture of γ-Al2O3, Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 (rhombohedral structure: R 3 ¯ c ). On the other hand, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) significantly dropped when the activation temperature reached 500 °C, where the catalysts are probably mainly cubic-like crystals representing a large number of α-AlF3 (cubic structure: Pm-3m). 3.1.4 MAS NMR spectroscopy Superpositions of the 27Al MAS NMR spectra of γ-Al2O3 and the catalysts activated at different temperatures were shown in Fig. 5 . Since all the spectra were measured under the same conditions, the intensities and widths of the signals can be compared. In Fig. 5(a), the 27Al NMR spectra of γ-Al2O3 and the catalyst activated at 350 °C both showed two distinct resonances, one at about 7 ppm attributed to the octahedral aluminum environment(AlVI) and the other at 66 ppm assigned to the tetrahedral aluminum environment(AlIV) [26], where the spinning sidebands were paralleled as single-high-low type and the intensity of each group was comparable. By contrast, the peak at 7 ppm slightly decreased and distorted at −15 ppm because of the fluorination of Al-O species where the oxygen atoms in the aluminum oxide matrix were replaced by fluorine atoms resulting in a line broadening toward higher field [34], which further confirmed that there is low-level fluorination at 350 °C between γ-Al2O3 and CHF3. Compared with the spectrum of catalyst activated at 350 °C, the AlIV and AlVI resonances belonging to γ-Al2O3 significantly decreased but remained when the temperature increased to 400 °C or 450 °C, suggesting the presence of γ-Al2O3 which can be also distinguished from the distribution of spinning side bands. Besides, the low-level fluorinated signal at −15 ppm sharply increased and shifted toward the higher field at −16 ppm which can be assigned to Al in an octahedral AlF6 environment of α-AlF3. The only main difference between the spectra of the catalysts activated at 400 °C and 450 °C in Fig. 5(b) is the signal strength, where the higher the temperature, the stronger the fluorination, the weaker the γ-Al2O3 signals and the stronger the octahedral AlF6 signals. As we can see from Fig. 6 (c), when the activation temperature increased to 500 °C, the signals of γ-Al2O3 completely disappeared and the spinning sidebands changed to follow the unimodal distribution and their intensity gradually decreased around the main peak at −16 ppm. In addition, there was no distinction between the two spectra in Fig. 5(c) and (d), indicating that γ-Al2O3 no longer existed when the activation temperature exceeded 500 °C. The identification of fluorine species in 19F MAS NMR spectra of fluorinated γ-Al2O3 at 350 °C, 400 °C and 450 °C shown in Fig. 6 was interpreted using the chemical shift scale introduced by Chupas et al. [35] . In the low-level fluorination, the lower field signal at −134 ppm corresponded to the [AlFxO6-x] unit where the oxygen was dominant with a trace amount of fluorine. However, with the increase of fluorine, the resonance will shift toward the higher field due to the stronger inductive effect. Thus, the relatively higher signal at around −150 ppm could be [AlF3O3] or [AlF4O2] and the resonance at −173 ppm was consistent with an octahedral AlF6 environment. By contrast, the signal at −148 ppm in Fig. 6(b) significantly decreased and disappeared in Fig. 6(c), while the signal at −173 ppm distinctly increased in both cases due to the further fluorination indicating the gradual formation of α-AlF3. Overall, the 19F MAS NMR spectra revealed that γ-Al2O3 was first fluorinated to various Al2O3(F), and then became α-AlF3. Based on the above XRD and MAS NMR spectroscopy results, the fluorination at different activation temperatures can be rationally explained using XPS curve fitting (shown in Fig. S3). When activated at 350 °C, γ-Al2O3 was first fluorinated to Al2O3(F). As the activation temperature gradually increased, more and more γ-Al2O3 was fluorinated to Al2O3(F), while part of Al2O3(F) was further fluorinated to α-AlF3 ( R 3 ¯ c ). In particular, the content of Al2O3(F) reached its highest at 450 °C. However, as the activation temperature reached 500 °C or even higher, γ-Al2O3 disappeared with Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 ( R 3 ¯ c ) become α-AlF3 (Pm-3m). These results could confirm the previous speculation that amorphous particles are a mixture of γ-Al2O3, Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 ( R 3 ¯ c ), while cubic-like crystals are large quantities of α-AlF3 (Pm-3m). Therefore, the catalyst deactivation was caused by the change in catalyst composition and morphology. 3.1.5 Acid properties To figure out why the catalytic activity varies with the composition and morphology, the amount and strength of acid sites were analyzed by NH3-TPD tests. The desorption profiles depicted in Fig. 7 describe the overall strength distribution of the acid sites, and the total acid sites are listed in Table 3 . There are mainly two desorption peaks, one is below 250 °C and the other is at around 500 °C. According to Song [36], these two peaks can be ascribed to acid sites with weak and strong strength respectively. As activation temperature increased from 350 °C to 550 °C, the amount of desorbed NH3 gradually decreased, whereas the density of acid sites increased due to the sharp decrease of surface area. When activated at 350 °C, the typical NH3 desorption temperature of 197 °C could represent the presence of γ-Al2O3 [34], and that of 493 °C could represent the formation of amorphous Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3. With the activation temperature further increased, most γ-Al2O3 was fluorinated to Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 and catalyst particles gradually grew, resulting in a mild increase in acid strength and a decrease in acid sites respectively. Therefore, it was inferred that Al2O3(F), with a moderate density of acid sites, is conducive to HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization. On the other hand, the types of acid sites were investigated using the pyridine adsorption method [37,38]. The lone-pair electron of the nitrogen atom of pyridine can either bind coordinatively to Lewis acid sites (LPy) or interact with acidic OH groups to form pyridinium cations or pyridine adsorbed via hydrogen bridge bond, Brønsted acid sites (BPy) [39]. Thus, the type of acid sites over the catalyst can be distinguished through the different ring vibration modes of the pyridine molecules depicted in FT-IR spectra. For example, the bands at approximately 1445 cm−1, 1575 cm−1 and 1615 cm−1 refer to the 19b, 8b and 8a ring vibration mode of pyridine respectively, which are all coordinatively bonded to Lewis acid sites. While 19a ring vibration mode of pyridine can be observed at about 1493 cm−1, indicating that the pyridine is either coordinatively bonded to Lewis acid sites or Brønsted acid sites. Besides, the broad band at 1540–1550 cm−1 reveals the 19b ring vibration mode of pyridine corresponds to hydrogen bonded pyridine to quasi-Brønsted acid sites [37,38]. Fig. 8 (i) shows the FT-IR spectra after the adsorption of pyridine on the catalyst surface after 150 °C evacuation, where two distinct absorption spectrums are observed at 1445 cm−1 and 1615 cm−1, suggesting that Lewis acid sites are dominant on the catalyst surface. In comparison, the adsorption spectrum belonging to Brønsted acid sites appears insignificant at 1540–1550 cm−1. When evacuated at 150 °C, the number of Lewis acid sites listed in Table 4 decreased as the activation temperature increased from 350 °C to 450 °C, but it turned into an increasing trend when activated above 450 °C. By contrast, the density of Lewis acid sites increases on the contrary due to the sharp decrease in surface area. In addition, as γ-Al2O3 gradually fluorinated with the increase of activation temperature, the bands both in Fig. 8(i) and 8(ii) at 1615 cm−1 gradually shift to higher wavenumbers on the whole suggesting the generation of higher strength Lewis acid sites [37], which is consistent with the acid strength changes described in NH3-TPD results. According to Wander [40], the Lewis acid sites in the rhombohedral α-AlF3 structure are covered by the fluorine ions in the outermost layer leading to weak Lewis acid properties. However, Chaudhuri found the occurrence of potentially strong Lewis acid sites on the cubic α-AlF3 particles [41] . To sum up, all these results demonstrate that HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization prefers to occur at Lewis acid sites with a moderate density and acid strength, whereas strong Lewis acid sites are bad for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization. 3.2 Catalyst lifetime evaluation When activated at the best activation temperature (450 °C), the variation in catalytic activity was explored by changing the activation time (see supporting information Fig. S4). It can be concluded that more and more γ-Al2O3 was fluorinated to Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 ( R 3 ¯ c ) with the extension of activation time, leading to a mild decrease in the conversion of HCFO-1233(E) and an increase in the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z). To improve the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z), the reaction conditions were optimized as well, including reaction temperature and contact time (see supporting information Figs. S5 and S6). In both cases, the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) increased with reaction temperature and contact time, whereas the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) decreased on the contrary. Taking both factors into consideration, 270 °C and 30 s were decided as the best reaction temperature and contact time respectively. Herein, catalyst lifetime was evaluated under optimal catalyst preparation conditions (activation temperature: 450 °C, activation time: 48 h) and reaction conditions (reaction temperature: 270 °C, contact time: 30 s). As we can see from Fig. 9 , the conversion of HCFO-1233zd(E) fluctuated a little bit, but overall was on a downward trend dropping from 10% to around 6%, while the selectivity of HCFO-1233zd(Z) slightly increased and nearly stabilized at 97%. The reason for the deactivation of the catalyst was analyzed by XRD, XPS, N2 physisorption and SEM. As illustrated in Fig. S7, the peak intensity of α-AlF3 at 2θ = 25° slightly increased, and the (122) crystal plane at 2θ = 59° was exposed after 100 h evaluation, resulting in the decrease of surface area and total pore volume, which are consistent with the data changes in Table S1. Besides, the elemental composition on catalyst surface slightly changed even after 100 h evaluation. However, the morphologies of the fresh and spent catalysts presented in Fig. 10 (a) and Fig. 10(b) respectively have significantly changed from the initial amorphous particles to the cubic structure after 100 h evaluation. How does the crystal structure change? According to Kim and Kang [42], the crystal growth process can be affected by other crystal structures. Given this, we proposed a reasonable explanation that residual γ-Al2O3 was fluorinated by HCFO-1233zd(E) to form needle-like structures shown in Fig. 10(c) on the surface, and this kind of new structure induced the amorphous Al2O3(F) to reorganize and give cubic structures. With the formation of cubic structures, the Lewis acid properties were enhanced because many of the Lewis acid sites were located on the edges and corners [41], therefore leading to catalyst deactivation. 4 Conclusions In this study, γ-Al2O3 and CHF3 were used as the catalyst precursor and activating reagent respectively to prepare a series of catalysts under different activation conditions, the effects of crystal structure, composition and acidic properties on the HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization activity were investigated and summarized as follows: (1) The amorphous particles composed of γ-Al2O3, Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 ( R 3 ¯ c ) at 450 °C exhibit high catalytic activity for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization. (2) HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization occurs at Lewis acid sites with a moderate density and acid strength. (3) Strong Lewis acid sites are not conducive to HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization. (4) γ-Al2O3 can be fluorinated by HCFO-1233zd(E) to form needle-like structures which could induce the amorphous Al2O3(F) particles to reorganize and give cubic particles, where the Lewis acid properties were enhanced, leading to catalyst deactivation. On the whole, a safe and effective method for preparing catalysts for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization is provided, which supplies a route for consuming high greenhouse gas (CHF3) at the same time so that fluorine atoms can be utilized as much as possible. The above study results complement the basic research on HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization catalysts and clarify the catalyst deactivation mechanism, which could be useful in the design of highly efficient catalyst for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization and can be used as a reference for other isomerization reactions. coredata.dc:description: As an environmentally friendly cleaning agent, Z-1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233zd(Z)) can realize industrial production by the isomerization of HCFO-1233zd(E). Herein, various isomerization catalysts with different structures, compositions and acid properties were prepared through the fluorination of γ-Al2O3 with CHF3 by controlling the activation conditions. For the first time, the catalysts for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization were systematically studied by XRD, N2 physisorption, XPS, SEM, MAS NMR spectroscopy, NH3-TPD and py-IR. The active site of this reaction was revealed and the catalyst deactivation mechanism was proposed. It turned out that HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization prefers to occur at Lewis acid sites with moderate density and strength. The amorphous particles composed of γ-Al2O3, Al2O3(F) and α-AlF3 ( R 3 ¯ c ) at 450 °C exhibit highly catalytic activity for HCFO-1233zd(E) isomerization. After 100 h evaluation, it was found that residual γ-Al2O3 can be fluorinated by HCFO-1233zd(E) to form needle-like structures which could induce the amorphous Al2O3(F) particles to reorganize and give cubic structures, where the Lewis acid properties were enhanced, leading to catalyst deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation on fluorinated alumina catalysts prepared by the fluorination of γ-Al2O3 with CHF3 for the isomerization of E-1-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene
